name: Thunder
desc: The PER4MAX Thunder is an elite performance sports wheelchair built by the best for the best!  Offered in different configurations depending on sport, the Thunder has propelled elite athletes for decades in an array of sports! Crush the courts in our feather light tennis model with it’s eliminated front bumper and extended 5th wheel!  Ball with the best of them in a sturdy custom fit tapered lightweight basketball chair. Take on the softball field, rugby courts, lacrosse field, or running trail with The PER4MAX Thunder!!  The Thunder is hand built in the USA with aircraft quality aluminum and custom P4X machined parts highly scrutinized to produce a precise end product!

options.name: Basketball
options.desc: Wheelchairs designed for basketball have a front cowling that prevents your wheels from getting tangled up with your opponent’s wheels.

options.name: Softball / Tennis
options.desc: Sport wheelchairs that are not made for the basketball court have no need for the front cowling.  Leave it off to save weight and gain maneuverability.  Tennis chairs have a slightly longer 5th wheel for added stability.

options.name: Same as Frame
options.desc: A sleek and classic look: match your backrest, footrest, and side guards to the color of the frame.

options.name: Custom
options.desc: Customize your rig with your team colors!  Change the color of the backrest, footrest, and side guards.

options.name: Rigid 5th Wheel & Rigid Back Rest
options.desc: A rigid backrest allows for the center of gravity to be adjusted after the chair has been built. A single fifth wheel support in back provides stability while allowing increased center of gravity to increase performance and agility.  The fifth wheel comes Standard on all Thunder Models with a 72mm Micro caster float adjusted to factory specs.

options.name: Dual Rigid 5th Wheel & Rigid Back Rest
options.desc: A rigid backrest allows for the center of gravity to be adjusted after the chair has been built. The Dual rear wheel option is recommended for advanced athletes looking to accelerate their game by allowing a more aggressive center of gravity setting while providing stability when cornering at high speeds.  Recommended by team per4max for athletes at every level the addition of the second rear wheel is a much more stable and predictable option for The PER4MAX Thunder.

options.name: Rigid 5th Wheel & Continuous Back Rest
options.desc: A continuous backrest is stronger than a rigid backrest, but it's not adjustable. A single fifth wheel support in back provides stability while allowing increased center of gravity to increase performance and agility. The fifth wheel comes Standard on all Thunder Models with a 72mm Micro caster float adjusted to factory specs.

options.name: Dual Rigid 5th Wheel & Continuous Back Rest
options.desc: A continuous backrest is stronger than a rigid backrest, but it's not adjustable.  The Dual rear wheel option is recommended for advanced athletes looking to accelerate their game by allowing a more aggressive center of gravity setting while providing stability when cornering at high speeds.  Recommended by team per4max for athletes at every level the addition of the second rear wheel is a much more stable and predictable option for The PER4MAX Thunder.

options.name: Removable 5th Wheel & Rigid Backrest
options.desc: A rigid backrest allows for the center of gravity to be adjusted after the chair has been built. Experience the added benefits of a 5th wheel with the convenience of removing it seconds.  The removable 5th wheel is great for individuals with smaller cars with limited space!  When you are ready to compete simply install the 5th wheel clamp it down and off you go!

options.name: Standard
options.desc: The standard upholstery is strong, tear resistant, and high quality.

options.name: Leather Trim
options.desc: Leather trimmed upholstery to adds extra strength and style to your backrest and seat.

options.name: Tension Backrest
options.desc: Tension adjustable upholstery allows you to adjust the Nylon supports quickly to achieve the perfect lumbar support.

options.name: None, I'll supply my own
options.desc: If you have wheels from an old sports chair or you'll be buying wheels separately, choose this option.  We will still need to know that size wheels you will be planning to use in order to configure the chair correctly.

options.name: 24" Standard Spoke Wheels
options.desc: Our standard wheel is a 24" wire spoke wheel made by Sun Components.  This wheel is lightweight, stiff, and high quality.

options.name: 25", 26", or 27" Wire Spoke Wheels
options.desc: Our standard wheel is a wire spoke wheel made by Sun Components.  This wheel is lightweight, stiff, and high quality.

options.name: Spinergy Wheels
options.desc: For serious athletes, the Spinergy wheels are the only choice. Spinergy wheels use PBO spokes that absorb impacts and will stay true no matter what.

options.name: Spinergy SLX
options.desc: Get even more durability with 24 of Spinergy's 4mm patented PBO FIBER spokes in a wheel designed to perform in the most demanding contact sports. This wheel is responsive, offers extreme durability and is ideal for contact sport players. If you demand a lightweight quick accelerating and maneuverable wheel, the Sport Lite Extreme could be your answer. This wheel looks awesome, is stylish and allows you to focus on the game, not equipment failures.

options.name: Spinergy SLX R-10
options.desc: The SLX R-10 is a tried and true design from Spinergy with a strong and durable, stylish radial laced spoke pattern. Take the benefits of the SLX 24 spoke wheel and add the durability of a 5/8" axle. Mostly used in contact sports where the 1/2" axles tend to bend the most. These wheels deliver confidence and performance on the courts.

options.name: Hard Anodized 6 tab
options.desc: The standard hard anodized aluminum hand rim can take a beating and keep running true.  Remember to choose close or far mounting depending on your preferences.

options.name: Hard Anodized 12 tab
options.desc: For extra rigidity, choose the 12 tab mounted hand rim.   Remember to choose close or far mounting.

options.name: Titanium
options.desc: NOTE: only available on 25" and 26" wheels. Titanium is lighter and stronger than the standard aluminum hand rims.

options.name: Vinyl Coated
options.desc: Top quality coated handrim that provides extra grip and control.  Remember to choose close or far mounting depending on your preferences.

options.name: Other
options.desc: Want something else?  Write it in here, and one of our customer service representatives will email you after your order is placed.

options.name: None, I'll supply my own.
options.desc: Supply your own hand rims.

options.name: High Pressure Tires
options.desc: Our standard high pressure PRIMO tire is great for the court!

options.name: Schwalbe Speed Air Tires
options.desc: Choose these lightweight tires to amp up your performance.

options.name: Schwalbe Right Run Tires
options.desc: High quality Schwalbe tires with colorful options!

options.name: Kenda Court Iron Cap Tires
options.desc: Experience the protection of Iron Cap Puncture Resistant Technology from Kenda on Wheelchair Tires for Court or Everyday Use.

options.name: Other
options.desc: Want something else?  Write it in here, and one of our customer service representatives will email you after your order is placed.

options.name: None, I'll supply my own.
options.desc: Supply your own tires.

options.name: 3" (72mm) Micro
options.desc: Our standard 3" casters roll great in all conditions.

options.name: 59mm Micro
options.desc: For even lower rolling resistance, these extra-small 59mm casters roll great on the court, but are slightly more prone to develop flutter in old age.

options.name: Other
options.desc: Want something else?  Write it in here, and one of our customer service representatives will email you after your order is placed.

options.name: 7000 Series Frame
options.desc: To up your game, we'll build your chair out of 7000 series aluminum which reduces weight and increases rigidity.

options.name: Hard Cushion
options.desc: Many players like a firm surface for competitive play.  Specify a hard cushion for added height. Often chosen in combination with Plastic seat plate option and max seat height 21" Front and 21" Back.

options.name: Special Cushion
options.desc: Have a special cushion that you like?  Write it in here and a customer server rep will email you after you place your order to confirm.  Some common options are Stimulite, RoHo, or Jay

options.name: Plastic Seat Plate
options.desc: An ABS plastic plate is attached to welded supports under the seat frame to allow user achieve max seat height or to eliminate seat upholstery sag. /n*Typically used in combination with a sold 2/î foam cushion found in the misc section in our options. /n** Not available on the Thunder Adjustable.

options.name: Foam Impact Guards
options.desc: Protect your chair while in transit with foam or leather impact guards.

options.name: Leather Impact Guards
options.desc: Protect your chair while in transit with foam or leather impact guards.

options.name: Waist Strap
options.desc: Typical Sizes: 10-12" : The correct strapping is important for competition.  Our straps use the same ratchet system as snowboard bindings to get that snug fit.  If you normally use a waist strap, specify it here, and we will calculate the correct size for you.

options.name: Lap Strap
options.desc: Typical Size: 8" : The correct strapping is important for competition.  Our straps use the same ratchet system as snowboard bindings to get that snug fit.  If you normally use a lap strap, specify it here, and we will calculate the correct size for you.

options.name: Foot Strap
options.desc: Typical Size: 8" : The correct strapping is important for competition.  Our straps use the same ratchet system as snowboard bindings to get that snug fit.  If you normally use a foot strap, specify it here, and we will calculate the correct size for you.

options.name: None
options.desc: No miscellaneous options.

options.name: Other
options.desc: Want something else?  Write it in here, and one of our customer service representatives will email you after your order is placed.

measures.name: Seat Width
measures.desc: The distance between the outside of the seat tube on one side of the chair to the outside of the seat tube on the other, at the hips.
measures.details: Seat width helps determines how the frame fits your body and how much side to side stability you will have. A tighter seat width provides a sleeker appearance and increases your lateral stability. It also gives you easier access to the push rims. /nTiArrow uses a thin tube to outline the shape of the side guard, however. This adds rigidity to the frame and increases your lateral stability, but it also makes the frame fit your body a little differently. We suggest choosing a seat width that is .5" wider than you would otherwise get to ensure a comfortable fit.
measures.tip: An easy way to measure seat width is to press a book firmly against either hip and measure between them.
measures.gifDesc: As the seat width narrows, trunk stability increases. /n As the seat widens, trunk stability decreases.

measures.name: Taper (Knee Width) $125
measures.desc: The width of the chair at the knee. (inside of tube to inside of tube)
measures.details: Taper allows a more tailored fit and helps to increase chair control and overall feel while assisting to achieve proper body alignment.  To measure taper place your hand between your legs and measure the outside distance of the contact patch where your legs meet the frame. If you select no taper, the knee width will be the same as seat width.
measures.tip: Greater taper will make it easier to maneuver on the court.
measures.gifDesc: You gain more control and body alignment as the taper increases.

measures.name: Seat Depth
measures.desc: The distance from your seat back to the front of your seat (typically where your seat cushion ends). Seat depth helps determine how pressure is distributed through your legs.
measures.details: To balance comfort and pressure distribution, we recommend a seat depth that is 2-3 inches (5-8 cm) shorter than the length of your upper leg.  Too short a seat and the pressure may be too concentrated in your upper thighs, however too long a seat may press uncomfortably against the back of your lower leg.
measures.tip: We recommend that the seat depth be 5-8 cm (2-3 inches) shorter that the length of your upper leg. This will provide you maximum leg support while allowing you to comfortably adjust your knee angle.
measures.gifDesc: As seat depth decreases, pressure increases.

measures.name: Total Length
measures.desc: The distance from the front of your backrest to the point where the seat bends at the knee.
measures.details: Per4max defines the total length as the distance from the front of your backrest to the point where the frame bends at the knee.  Most athletes like to have at least a few inches of metal sticking out in front of their knees to protect them during competition.  Additionally, a frame that is slightly longer gives you a place to grab onto and steady your self.
measures.tip: The total length should be long enough so that the frame sticks out a little past your knees.
measures.gifDesc: As the total length increases, you have more room to grab.

measures.name: Rear Seat Height
measures.desc: The distance from the back of your seat to the floor.
measures.details: The rear seat height effects how you interact with your wheels.  Sitting a little taller will give you an easier push and the research suggests that it is better for the long term health of your shoulders.  However, a lower seat height can really enhance your stability if you have low trunk control. Most therapists say that the correct seat height is one where your fingers touch the rear axle when you hang your arms straight down from your shoulders.  Measure your current rear seat height and see if you would like to make any adjustments.
measures.tip: Most therapists say that the correct seat height is one where your fingers touch the rear axle when you hang your arms straight down from your shoulders.
measures.gifDesc: As the seat height increases, push ergonomics get better, but stability decreases.

measures.name: Front Seat Height
measures.desc: The distance from the front of your seat to the floor.
measures.details: The interaction between the front seat height and rear seat height creates a seat that tilts back slightly. Therapists refer to this property as "Dump".  The more Dump you have, the more your seat tips backwards. If the front seat height is significantly higher than the rear seat height, it will serve hold you in the seat a little better and give you more trunk stability.
measures.tip: Higher front seat height gives you more Dump.  High classified players will typically use little or no Dump.

measures.name: Backrest Height
measures.desc: The distance from the top of the seat tube to the top of the seat post. The height of the seat back plays a role in providing trunk stability.
measures.details: The height of the backrest, in combination with the relation between front and rear seat height, helps provide trunk stability. In determining seatback height it is important to assess your level of trunk control as well as the amount of times you need to lean back to perform an activity of daily living (cooking, cleaning, dressing, undressing, etc.). When measuring seatback height, remember to factor in the height of the cushion you will be sitting on. On a TiArrow frame it is easier to lower a seatback that is too high than to raise a seatback that is too low.
measures.tip: The easiest way to determine backrest height is to assess how satisfied you are with your current backrest height and make the necessary adjustments.
measures.gifDesc: Lower backrest height gives you more range of motion but less trunk stability.

measures.name: Backrest Angle
measures.desc: The angle of the backrest in relation to the ground.
measures.details: Most people want a backrest angle of 0 degrees which makes it perpendicular to the ground.  However, different injury types require different support, so look at your old chair for guidance.
measures.tip: Look at your old chair for reference on the back angle.  Different types of injuries require different types of support.
measures.gifDesc: As the angle increases, trunk stability increases but explosiveness decreases.
measures.writeInLabel: Other Back Angle (optionally perpendicular to the floor or seat)

measures.name: Foot Width
measures.desc: The width of the flat portion of the foot rest.
measures.details: Foot rest width is generally a personal preference.  Some people like the comfort of a wide foot rest, where others prefer the compactness and maneuverability of narrow foot rest.  Make certain that your foot rest is at least as wide as your feet when wearing a pair of shoes.
measures.tip: The foot rest should be at least as wide as your feet when wearing a pair of shoes.
measures.gifDesc: As the foot rest width increases, the size of the wheelchair increases.

measures.name: Lower Leg Length
measures.desc: The distance from the back of your knee to the bottom of your foot while wearing shoes.
measures.details: A foot rest should be just high enough to hold your feet securely.  This will push your knees up and take pressure off the back of your legs.    To calculate the footrest height, we just need to know the length from the back of your knee to the bottom of your feet while wearing shoes. The height of a foot rest is adjustable so you will be able to fine tune it after your chair has been built.  NOTE: A range less than 15" may result in a special footrest.
measures.tip: The foot rest should be just high enough so that your feet are properly supported.
measures.gifDesc: As the foot rest height increases, pressure on the back of your legs decreases.

measures.name: Backrest to Center Axle
measures.desc: Backrest to Center Axle, also refered to as Center of Gravity. The distance from the front of the seatback post to the center of the axle. Axle position is one of the most important factors in determining the agility of your wheelchair.
measures.details: The standard measurement is 5" with a single fifth wheel or 6" with dual rear wheels.  The axle position affects how easy it is to push and turn your chair (agility) as well as how easy it is for your chair to tip over backwards.  The further forward you place your axle the easier it is to push and turn, though it is also easier for your chair to tip over backwards.   The axle position on your basketball chair will generally be further forward than the axle on your day chair since you have the 5th wheel to prevent tipping backwards.
measures.tip: The axle position on your basketball chair will generally be further forward than the axle on your day chair.
measures.gifDesc: As the axle position moves forwards, the chair gets more tippy but also more agile.

measures.name: Center Axle To Caster Housing (Wheelbase)
measures.desc: The distance from the axle to the center of the casters.  On a car, you would call this the wheelbase.
measures.details: To keep you chair agile, Per4max tries to keep your front casters in close to the center of gravity.  Generally, a 24" rear wheel will warrant a 15" wheel base, and a 27" rear wheel will warrant an 18" wheelbase.
measures.tip: Generally, a 24" rear wheel will warrant a 15" wheel base, and a 27" rear wheel will warrant an 18" wheelbase.
measures.gifDesc: As the casters move forward, the chair becomes more stable, but less agile.

measures.name: Caster Housing To Front Foot Plate
measures.desc: The distance between the front of the footplate and the center of the caster housing.
measures.details: It's a good idea to have your feet and legs tucked away safely under your body.  It keeps your mass closer to the center of gravity making it easier to pivot and turn. 6" is standard, but we also offer between 5" and 7"
measures.tip: We generally recommend 6" for this measurement, but refer to your old chair if you are unsure.
measures.gifDesc: As your feet move closer to your center of gravity, it becomes easier to pivot and turn.

measures.name: Side Wheel Clearance
measures.desc: The distance between the side guards and the inside edge of the wheel.
measures.details: You can generally get more power when your wheels are closer to your body.
measures.tip: We recomend 1.5" as standard.
measures.gifDesc: As the wheels move out, thumb space increases but ergonomics decrease.

measures.name: Camber Angle
measures.desc: The angle of the wheels with respect to the ground.
measures.details: Camber is imperative for a stable ride and easy pivoting.  Generally, more camber will improve both of these aspects.  However, too much camber makes the chair very large and harder to fit through tight gaps.
measures.tip: If you are uncertain of the right camber for you, 15 degrees is a good safe bet.
measures.gifDesc: As camber increases, stability and pivot speed increase, but size also increases.

measures.name: Axle Size
measures.desc: The diameter of the Axle
measures.details: If you are supplying your own wheels, we need to know what size axles they use.  The standard is 1/2", but R10 Spinergy Wheels have big 5/8" axles to prevent bending.  If you need help selecting this, please write in the comments box.
measures.tip: Most wheels use 1/2" axles, but the R10 Spinergy Wheel and a few others use 5/8" axles.
measures.gifDesc: Bigger axles are more resistant to being bent.

name: Thunder Adjustable
desc: The Thunder Adjustable is the most versatile performance sports chair on the market today! It is made of optional 6061 T6 or optional 7000 series aluminum.  With the front seat height fixed, the rear seat height is easily adjusted in seconds utilizing P4X custom machined parts and clamps used on bicycle seats.  Simply slide the seat to the desired height and lock into that position!  Backrest angle and option height adjust post allow you to adjust this chair to vertually any user.  Also comes with center of gravity adjustment and lower leg length adjustability to find the perfect fit!  Great for new wheelchair athletes and programs searching for chairs that fit everybody.  Also great for the universal athlete looking for a great all around chair that can be adjusted to your sport of choice.  Contact your local Representative or us for more information on the Thunder Adjustable Sport Wheelchair!

Additionally, a frame that is slightly longer gives you a place to grab onto and steady your self.
measures.tip: The total length should be long enough so that the frame sticks out a little past your knees.
measures.gifDesc: As the total length increases, you have more room to grab.

measures.name: Rear Seat Height
measures.desc: The distance from the back of your seat to the floor.
measures.details: The rear seat height effects how you interact with your wheels.  Sitting a little taller will give you an easier push and the research suggests that it is better for the long term health of your shoulders.  However, a lower seat height can really enhance your stability if you have low trunk control. Most therapists say that the correct seat height is one where your fingers touch the rear axle when you hang your arms straight down from your shoulders.  Measure your current rear seat height and see if you would like to make any adjustments.
measures.tip: Most therapists say that the correct seat height is one where your fingers touch the rear axle when you hang your arms straight down from your shoulders.
measures.gifDesc: As the seat height increases, push ergonomics get better, but stability decreases.

measures.name: Front Seat Height
measures.desc: The distance from the front of your seat to the floor.
measures.details: The interaction between the front seat height and rear seat height creates a seat that tilts back slightly. Therapists refer to this property as "Dump".  The more Dump you have, the more your seat tips backwards. If the front seat height is significantly higher than the rear seat height, it will serve hold you in the seat a little better and give you more trunk stability.
measures.tip: Higher front seat height gives you more Dump.  High classified players will typically use little or no Dump.

measures.name: Backrest Height
measures.desc: The distance from the top of the seat tube to the top of the seat post. The height of the seat back plays a role in providing trunk stability.
measures.details: The height of the backrest, in combination with the relation between front and rear seat height, helps provide trunk stability. In determining seatback height it is important to assess your level of trunk control as well as the amount of times you need to lean back to perform an activity of daily living (cooking, cleaning, dressing, undressing, etc.). When measuring seatback height, remember to factor in the height of the cushion you will be sitting on. On a TiArrow frame it is easier to lower a seatback that is too high than to raise a seatback that is too low.
measures.tip: The easiest way to determine backrest height is to assess how satisfied you are with your current backrest height and make the necessary adjustments.
measures.gifDesc: Lower backrest height gives you more range of motion but less trunk stability.

measures.name: Backrest Angle
measures.desc: The angle of the backrest in relation to the ground.
measures.details: Most people want a backrest angle of 0 degrees which makes it perpendicular to the ground.  However, different injury types require different support, so look at your old chair for guidance.
measures.tip: Look at your old chair for reference on the back angle.  Different types of injuries require different types of support.
measures.gifDesc: As the angle increases, trunk stability increases but explosiveness decreases.
measures.writeInLabel: Other Back Angle (optionally perpendicular to the floor or seat)

measures.name: Foot Width
measures.desc: The width of the flat portion of the foot rest.
measures.details: Foot rest width is generally a personal preference.  Some people like the comfort of a wide foot rest, where others prefer the compactness and maneuverability of narrow foot rest.  Make certain that your foot rest is at least as wide as your feet when wearing a pair of shoes.
measures.tip: The foot rest should be at least as wide as your feet when wearing a pair of shoes.
measures.gifDesc: As the foot rest width increases, the size of the wheelchair increases.

measures.name: Lower Leg Length
measures.desc: The distance from the back of your knee to the bottom of your foot while wearing shoes.
measures.details: A foot rest should be just high enough to hold your feet securely.  This will push your knees up and take pressure off the back of your legs.    To calculate the footrest height, we just need to know the length from the back of your knee to the bottom of your feet while wearing shoes. The height of a foot rest is adjustable so you will be able to fine tune it after your chair has been built.  NOTE: A range less than 15" may result in a special footrest.
measures.tip: The foot rest should be just high enough so that your feet are properly supported.
measures.gifDesc: As the foot rest height increases, pressure on the back of your legs decreases.

measures.name: Backrest to Center Axle
measures.desc: Backrest to Center Axle, also refered to as Center of Gravity. The distance from the front of the seatback post to the center of the axle. Axle position is one of the most important factors in determining the agility of your wheelchair.
measures.details: The standard measurement is 5" with a single fifth wheel or 6" with dual rear wheels.  The axle position affects how easy it is to push and turn your chair (agility) as well as how easy it is for your chair to tip over backwards.  The further forward you place your axle the easier it is to push and turn, though it is also easier for your chair to tip over backwards.   The axle position on your basketball chair will generally be further forward than the axle on your day chair since you have the 5th wheel to prevent tipping backwards.
measures.tip: The axle position on your basketball chair will generally be further forward than the axle on your day chair.
measures.gifDesc: As the axle position moves forwards, the chair gets more tippy but also more agile.

measures.name: Center Axle To Caster Housing (Wheelbase)
measures.desc: The distance from the axle to the center of the casters.  On a car, you would call this the wheelbase.
measures.details: To keep you chair agile, Per4max tries to keep your front casters in close to the center of gravity.  Generally, a 24" rear wheel will warrant a 15" wheel base, and a 27" rear wheel will warrant an 18" wheelbase.
measures.tip: Generally, a 24" rear wheel will warrant a 15" wheel base, and a 27" rear wheel will warrant an 18" wheelbase.
measures.gifDesc: As the casters move forward, the chair becomes more stable, but less agile.

measures.name: Caster Housing To Front Foot Plate
measures.desc: The distance between the front of the footplate and the center of the caster housing.
measures.details: It's a good idea to have your feet and legs tucked away safely under your body.  It keeps your mass closer to the center of gravity making it easier to pivot and turn. 6" is standard, but we also offer between 5" and 7"
measures.tip: We generally recommend 6" for this measurement, but refer to your old chair if you are unsure.
measures.gifDesc: As your feet move closer to your center of gravity, it becomes easier to pivot and turn.

measures.name: Side Wheel Clearance
measures.desc: The distance between the side guards and the inside edge of the wheel.
measures.details: You can generally get more power when your wheels are closer to your body.
measures.tip: We recomend 1.5" as standard.
measures.gifDesc: As the wheels move out, thumb space increases but ergonomics decrease.

measures.name: Camber Angle
measures.desc: The angle of the wheels with respect to the ground.
measures.details: Camber is imperative for a stable ride and easy pivoting.  Generally, more camber will improve both of these aspects.  However, too much camber makes the chair very large and harder to fit through tight gaps.
measures.tip: If you are uncertain of the right camber for you, 15 degrees is a good safe bet.
measures.gifDesc: As camber increases, stability and pivot speed increase, but size also increases.

measures.name: Axle Size
measures.desc: The diameter of the Axle
measures.details: If you are supplying your own wheels, we need to know what size axles they use.  The standard is 1/2", but R10 Spinergy Wheels have big 5/8" axles to prevent bending.  If you need help selecting this, please write in the comments box.
measures.tip: Most wheels use 1/2" axles, but the R10 Spinergy Wheel and a few others use 5/8" axles.
measures.gifDesc: Bigger axles are more resistant to being bent.
